H0.text: Archaebacteria are the kingdom into which scientists would classify organisms that thrive in hot water at 90 °C (194 °F) and do not need sunlight or oxygen to live.

H1.text: Fungi are the kingdom into which scientists would classify organisms that thrive in hot water at 90 °C (194 °F) and do not need sunlight or oxygen to live.

H2.text: Plantae is the kingdom into which scientists would classify organisms that thrive in hot water at 90 °C (194 °F) and do not require sunlight or oxygen to live.

H3.text: Protista is the kingdom scientists would classify organisms that thrive in hot water at 90 °C (194 °F) and do not need sunlight or oxygen to live.

A4.text: Archaea were initially classified as bacteria, receiving the name archaebacteria (, in the Archaebacteria kingdom), but this term has fallen out of use.

A5.text: Hyperthermophiles are particularly extreme thermophiles for which the optimal temperatures are above 80 °C (176 °F).

A6.text: Some are anaerobes that use the sulfur instead of oxygen as an electron acceptor during anaerobic cellular respiration.
